title: 334-B
statement: B. Eight Point Setstime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutGerald is very particular to eight point sets. He thinks that any decent eight point set must consist of all pairwise intersections of three distinct integer vertical straight lines and three distinct integer horizontal straight lines, except for the average of these nine points. In other words, there must be three integersx1,x2,x3and three more integersy1,y2,y3, such thatx1<x2<x3,y1<y2<y3and the eight point set consists of all points(xi,yj)(1 ≤i,j≤ 3), except for point(x2,y2).You have a set of eight points. Find out if Gerald can use this set?InputThe input consists of eight lines, thei-th line contains two space-separated integersxiandyi(0 ≤xi,yi≤ 106). You do not have any other conditions for these points.OutputIn a single line print word "respectable", if the given set of points corresponds to Gerald's decency rules, and "ugly" otherwise.ExamplesInput0 00 10 21 01 22 02 12 2OutputrespectableInput0 01 02 03 04 05 06 07 0OutputuglyInput1 11 21 32 12 22 33 13 2Outputugly

processed.result:
You are given a set of eight points on a 2D plane.  Each point is represented by its x and y coordinates.  

Determine if these points can be formed by:

* Three distinct horizontal lines, each defined by a y-coordinate.
* Three distinct vertical lines, each defined by an x-coordinate.

The points must be all the intersections of these lines, except for the point where the two lines defined by the middle y-coordinate and the middle x-coordinate intersect.

If the points can be formed this way, output "respectable". Otherwise, output "ugly".

You are given a set of eight points. Determine if these points can be formed by the intersection of three vertical lines and three horizontal lines, excluding the intersection of one specific pair of lines.
